qas.question: What is considered the inspired, inerrant word of God?
What do Jehovah Witnesses consider the science and history within the Bible to be?
Whose pronouncements within Jehovah Witnesses group are considered to carry almost as much weight as the Bible?
What are members of Jehovah Witnesses cautioned against reading?
What is there no provision for members of the Jehovah Witnesses to do in relation to the official teachings?
Who is the outside foremost authority on Jehovah's Witnesses?
How often do many Jehovah's Witnesses read other religions literature?
What religion gives their adherents a lot of leeway in regards to abiding by its doctrines?
How often does Watch Tower Society put out publications nowadays?
In what publication was Andrew Holden's ethnographic study of Jehovah's Witnesses published?

context: <a0_0>The entire Protestant canon<a0_0/> of scripture is considered the inspired, inerrant word of God. <b7_0>Jehovah's Witnesses<b7_0/> consider the Bible to be scientifically and historically <a1_0>accurate<a1_0/> and reliable and interpret much of it literally, but accept parts of it as symbolic. They consider the Bible to be the final authority for all their beliefs, although sociologist <b5_0>Andrew Holden<b5_0/>'s ethnographic study of the religion concluded that pronouncements of <a2_0>the Governing Body<a2_0/>, through Watch Tower Society publications, carry almost as much weight as the Bible. Regular personal Bible reading is <b6_0><b8_0>frequently<b8_0/><b6_0/> recommended; Witnesses are discouraged from formulating doctrines and "private ideas" reached through Bible research independent of <b9_0>Watch Tower Society<b9_0/> publications, and are cautioned against reading <a3_0>other religious literature<a3_0/>. Adherents are told to have "complete confidence" in the leadership, avoid skepticism about what is taught in the Watch Tower Society's literature, and "not advocate or insist on personal opinions or harbor private ideas when it comes to Bible understanding." The religion makes no provision for members to <a4_0>criticize or contribute<a4_0/> to official teachings and all Witnesses must abide by its doctrines and organizational requirements.
